messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

messages.name: get_code_snippet
messages.content: "174 :     public Partial(DateTimeFieldType[] types, int[] values) {\n175 :         this(types, values, null);\n176 :     }"

messages.name: get_code_snippet
get_code_snippet
messages.content: "334 :     protected DateTimeField getField(int index, Chronology chrono) {\n335 :         return iTypes[index].getField(chrono);\n336 :     }"

Title: Diagnosis of test `testConstructorEx7_TypeArray_intArray`
Details: The test `testConstructorEx7_TypeArray_intArray` is part of the class `org.joda.time.TestPartial_Constructors`. It tests the `Partial` class constructors with an array of `DateTimeFieldType` and an array of `int` values. The test verifies that when the `DateTimeFieldType` array contains duplicate or out-of-order elements, an `IllegalArgumentException` is thrown with the correct error message.

The test failure occurred in line 284 of the test method. To understand the bug, let's look at the code of the `Partial` class and the relevant methods.

The `Partial` class has multiple constructors. The first constructor, which takes `DateTimeFieldType[]` and `int[]` as arguments, simply calls another constructor with an additional `Chronology` argument. The second constructor initializes the instance variables and performs various validations on the input arguments.

The `Partial.getField(int, Chronology)` method returns the `DateTimeField` at the specified index of the `iTypes` array, using the provided `Chronology`. The `Partial.getChronology()` method returns the `Chronology` associated with this `Partial` instance. The `Partial.size()` method returns the length of the `iTypes` array.

To determine the cause of the bug, we need to examine the test code and the error message. The error message states that the types array must be in order from largest to smallest. Looking at the test code, we can see that the third test case (starting from line 281) passes an array of `DateTimeFieldType` with the order: `year`, `era`, `monthOfYear`.

Based on the error message and the failing test, it appears that the `Partial` constructor does not correctly validate the order of the `DateTimeFieldType` array. This is likely the cause of the bug.

Suggested fix:
- Update the `Partial` constructor to properly validate the order of the `DateTimeFieldType` array.

Code snippets:
- `org.joda.time.Partial.Partial(org.joda.time.DateTimeFieldType[], int[])`
- `org.joda.time.Partial.getField(int, org.joda.time.Chronology)`

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
